summary: This is an FBI daily briefing document from November 16, 2020, covering a wide range of national security, law enforcement, and political news. It includes a significant revelation about the Epstein case: a DOJ report stating the FBI wanted to arrest Jeffrey Epstein at a Virgin Islands beauty pageant before his plea deal, but the plan was halted by the U.S. Attorney's Office led by Alexander Acosta. The document also covers post-election politics, COVID-19, domestic terrorism, and various criminal investigations.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of a DOJ report revealing the FBI wanted to arrest him at a Virgin Islands beauty pageant in May 2007, but the plan was halted by the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, former Labor Secretary
persons.context: As U.S. Attorney, his office frowned on the FBI's plan to arrest Epstein in 2007, according to a DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility report.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of Operation LeGend arrests and as the recipient of a letter from assistant U.S. attorneys criticizing his memo on election 'irregularities'.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Central figure in post-election transition disputes, with Republicans and former officials calling for him to receive intelligence briefings.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Refusing to concede the 2020 election, spreading claims of voter fraud, and delaying the presidential transition.

persons.name: Rudy Giuliani
persons.context: Taking over Trump's election litigation team and spreading conspiracy theories about voting machines.

persons.name: John Kelly
persons.role: Former White House Chief of Staff
persons.context: Argued that Biden should receive intelligence briefings and that the delayed transition damages national security.

persons.name: Andrew McCabe
persons.context: Warned that further declassification of Trump-Russia investigation materials could be 'unflattering' for the president.

persons.name: Gretchen Whitmer
persons.context: Target of an alleged kidnapping plot by anti-government groups; new COVID-19 restrictions in Michigan.

persons.name: Adam Fox
persons.role: Alleged ringleader in Whitmer kidnap plot
persons.context: Accused of planning to storm the Michigan Capitol, take hostages, and televise executions.

persons.name: Gregory McMichael
persons.context: Charged with murder; bond denied after hearing included evidence of racial bias.

persons.name: Travis McMichael
persons.context: Charged with murder; bond denied after hearing included evidence of racial bias.

persons.name: Leonard Raye Moses
persons.context: Arrested by FBI after nearly 50 years on the run for a 1968 murder conviction.

persons.name: Alonzo Brooks
persons.context: Kansas man whose 2004 death is being investigated by the FBI as a potential hate crime.

persons.name: Christopher Krebs
persons.context: Reportedly facing ouster for rebutting election fraud claims; DHS acting secretary defying order to fire him.

persons.name: Chad Wolf
persons.context: Reportedly defying Trump's order to fire CISA Director Christopher Krebs.

persons.name: Michael Ellis
persons.role: Reported appointee as NSA General Counsel
persons.context: Appointment as NSA General Counsel is setting off alarm bells among experts as an attempt to politicize a career position.

persons.name: Anthony Fauci
persons.context: Urged Americans to wear masks and follow health guidelines amid COVID-19 surge.

persons.name: Moncef Slaoui
persons.role: Chief Scientific Advisor to Operation Warp Speed
persons.context: Stated 20 million Americans could receive a COVID-19 vaccine in December 2020.

connections.description: Acosta's U.S. Attorney's Office halted the FBI's 2007 plan to arrest Epstein, leading to the later non-prosecution agreement.
Giuliani is Trump's personal attorney leading his post-election legal challenges.
Fox is the alleged ringleader of a plot to kidnap Governor Whitmer.
Father and son charged together with the murder of Ahmaud Arbery.
Trump reportedly ordered the firing of Krebs, the CISA director.
Wolf, as acting DHS secretary, is reportedly defying the order to fire Krebs.

events.title: FBI Plan to Arrest Epstein Halted
events.description: The FBI planned to arrest Jeffrey Epstein at a Virgin Islands beauty pageant, but the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, led by Alexander Acosta, frowned on the plan.

events.title: DOJ Epstein Report Released
events.description: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility released a report on the 2008 Epstein prosecution, finding Acosta exercised 'poor judgment' but no misconduct, and revealing the aborted 2007 arrest plan.

events.title: Trump Rose Garden Vaccine Update
events.description: President Trump, in his first public remarks since election defeat, hailed vaccine progress but refused to concede, threatening to withhold vaccine from New York.

events.title: Arrest of 49-Year Fugitive
events.description: FBI arrested Leonard Raye Moses in Michigan, a fugitive who escaped custody in 1971 while serving a life sentence for a 1968 murder.

events.title: Bond Denied in Arbery Case
events.description: Judge denied bond to Gregory and Travis McMichael, charged with killing Ahmaud Arbery, citing concerns about bias and willingness to 'place the law in his own hands'.

events.title: SpaceX NASA Crew Launch
events.description: SpaceX launched four astronauts to the International Space Station on a NASA mission, the first operational crewed flight for SpaceX.

keyFacts: A DOJ report revealed the FBI wanted to arrest Jeffrey Epstein at a Virgin Islands beauty pageant in May 2007, but the plan was halted after the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, led by Alexander Acosta, frowned on it.

The DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility found Acosta exercised 'poor judgment' in the Epstein case but did not engage in misconduct, and determined Epstein was not assisting the government or serving as an 'intelligence asset'.

President Trump refused to concede the 2020 election, with his campaign filing numerous lawsuits and his administration delaying the transition to President-elect Joe Biden, despite calls from some Republicans to begin the process.
The FBI arrested Leonard Raye Moses, a fugitive who had escaped custody in 1971 and was living under an alias for nearly 50 years, after his fingerprints were matched following a minor theft arrest.

COVID-19 cases in the U.S. surpassed 11 million, with record hospitalizations and daily infections, leading multiple states to enact new restrictions as health officials urged mask-wearing and caution.
